part.caption: genbench.py (from waf)

ul.li: Waf version was somewhere after 1.5.1 (svn rev 5178)
Autotools versions: autoconf was 2.61, automake 1.10.1, libtool 1.5.26
Tool chain versions: gcc was 4.2.4, binutils was 2.18.0

part.part:
Since genbench.py produces a random setup, all these tests were run on the same genbench output, but each copied to its own directory to ensure they don't interfere with each others, i.e.
./genbench.py bench 50 100 15 5 cp -R bench bench-make cp -R bench bench-wonderbuild cp -R bench bench-waf cp -R bench bench-autotools cp -R bench bench-scons
This genbench.py invocation generates 10000 tiny interdependent C++ source and header files, to be built into 50 static libs.
In these benchmarks, all tools were run with silent/quiet option and/or > /dev/null.
All tests were run with 4 jobs on the same quad core system, ext2 filesystem on lvm/dmraid0 device, linux, gcc's C++ compiler.
The command lines used to run the tests were:
time make -C bench-make --jobs=4 --silent time ../wonderbuild.py --cxx-pic=no --jobs=4 --silent (cd bench-waf && time ../../waf/waf-light --jobs=4) > /dev/null time make -C bench-autotools --jobs=4 --silent > /dev/null (cd bench-scons && time scons --jobs=4 -Q) > /dev/null
The autotools generated only one makefile with everything (no recursive make invocation), and C++ dependencies were tracked with gcc while compiling; libtool was enabled, even for building static libs.
The toy makefiles generated were recursive, and C++ dependencies were tracked with the makedepend X utility.
Unlike waf and scons, which used a full-featured preprocessor to scan C++ dependencies, wonderbuild used a dumb include scanner, with no condition nor macro evaluation.
Waf and scons were tuned to use file timestamps comparisons rather than md5 sums.
Waf's parallel algorithm was set to "normal" (faster than "max parallel").
All tests were run at least seven times (first run not counted) and the average taken (sorry, didn't measure incertitude). Initial builds for scons and autools were not run seven times as they take AGES.
Configuration time was not counted (altough it's not really clear for scons).
Wonderbuild is a work-in-progress and not ready for production. Currently, it aims at building C++ code only, it's not documented, and lacks some essential features. If you need a complete and fast build tool, i suggest you try waf.
However, if you have an insterest in developping build tool systems, you can try wonderbuild with this benchmark with:
svn co https://psycle.svn.sourceforge.net/svnroot/psycle/branches/bohan/wonderbuild --ignore-externals cd wonderbuild/benchmarks ./genbench.py bench 50 100 15 5 cp -R bench bench-wonderbuild time ../wonderbuild.py --cxx-pic=no --silent # initial full build time ../wonderbuild.py --cxx-pic=no --silent # no-op build touch bench-wonderbuild/lib_17/class_17.h && time ../wonderbuild.py --cxx-pic=no --silent # small partial rebuild touch bench-wonderbuild/lib_17/*.h && time ../wonderbuild.py --cxx-pic=no --silent # big partial rebuild
The build dir is benchmarks/++wonderbuild
